claim.hypotheses_location: Literature review / hypotheses section, approximately pages 9–11 of the PDF
claim.statement_location: Introduction, approximately pages 2–3 of the PDF
claim.study_type: Observational (cross-sectional survey analysis using multilevel modelling)

data.sample_size: approximately 120,080 respondents (about 115,000 after excluding non-citizens and minorities)
data.access_details: Publicly available upon registration at https://www.europeansocialsurvey.org/
data.notes: Central and Eastern European countries were excluded; non-citizens and minorities removed; final analytic sample used three-level structure (individual, country-round, country).

method.description: The study employs three-level hierarchical linear modelling to examine whether concern about immigration predicts political distrust across Western European countries while controlling for individual- and country-level factors. Instrumental-variables checks and interaction terms assess potential endogeneity and contextual moderation (long-term immigration history, far-right strength).
steps: Download ESS rounds 1–4 and retain West European democracies only.
Exclude respondents who are non-citizens or belong to minority ethnic groups.
Construct dependent variables: distrust of parliament, politicians, and legal system (0–10, higher = more distrust).
Create main independent variable: immigration concern index from three items (0–10, higher = greater concern).
Assemble individual-level controls (economic dissatisfaction, interpersonal trust, social interaction frequency, unhappiness, winner effect, left–right placement, demographics).

Merge contextual variables: country-round economic indicators, far-right vote share, social-protection expenditure; country-level governance quality, GDP per capita, unemployment, long-term immigration history.
Specify three-level HLM (individual, country-round, country) predicting each distrust outcome.
Estimate models, including cross-level interactions between immigration concern and long-term immigration history and far-right strength.
Conduct robustness checks, including instrumental-variables analysis (first ESS round) to address endogeneity.
method.models: Three-level hierarchical linear (multilevel) models; instrumental-variables models for robustness.
method.outcome_variable: Political distrust (distrust of parliament, distrust of politicians, distrust of the legal system; each 0–10 scale)
method.independent_variables: Primary: concern about immigration index; contextual moderators: long-term immigration country, far-right party strength.
method.control_variables: Economic dissatisfaction (national economy, household income), interpersonal trust, social interaction frequency, general unhappiness, winner effect, left-right ideology, age, gender, education, GDP per capita, unemployment rate, social-protection expenditure, governance quality.

results.summary: Greater concern about immigration is significantly associated with higher levels of political distrust across Western European democracies. The effect remains after extensive controls and is stronger in countries with a long post-war immigration history. Far-right party strength modestly amplifies the relationship for distrust of the legal system. Economic dissatisfaction exerts an even larger effect than immigration concern, but immigration remains a robust predictor.
